Award.AwardTitle: High Resolution Genomic and Proteomic Analyses of a Microbial Transport Mechanism from Antarctic Marine Waters to Permanent Snowpack
Award.AbstractNarration:
The relatively pristine Antarctic continent with its extensive maritime zone represents a unique location on the planet to investigate the long distance aerial transport and deposition of marine microorganisms. The vast extent of new sea ice that forms each winter around the continent results in large numbers of frost flowers, delicate ice-crystal structures of high salt content that form on the surface of the ice and are readily dispersed by wind. The proposed research builds on earlier work in the Arctic and tests the new hypothesis that wind-borne frost flowers provide an effective mechanism for the transport of marine bacteria over long distances, one that can be uniquely sourced and tracked by the frost flower salt signature in the Antarctic realm. A highly resolved genomic snapshot of the microbial community will be acquired at each stage in the transport path, which will track decreasing fractions of the marine microbial community as it freezes into sea ice, incorporates into frost flowers, converts to aerosols, and ultimately deposits within continental snowpack. En route from sea ice to snowpack, marine bacteria will be exposed to an array of environmental stresses, including high salinity, low temperatures, UV light and potential desiccation. A parallel proteomic analysis will enable an evaluation of the microbial response to these extreme conditions and potential survival mechanisms that allow persistence or eventual colonization of deposition sites across Antarctica.

Current understanding of microbes in the Antarctic atmosphere is based on a limited number of microscopic and culture-based assays and a single report of low-resolution 16S RNA gene sequence analysis. The research will broadly impact understanding of atmospheric microbiology, from source to deposition, and various issues of microbial survival, colonization, endemism, and diversity under extreme conditions. In addition to venues that reach the scientific community, the research team will develop a permanent multi-media and artifact-based exhibit on Antarctic Microbial Transport that will be showcased at Seattle's Pacific Science Center (PSC), which educates nearly a million visitors annually.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This pilot project involved working under extreme conditions during late winter of 2011 in coastal Antarctica, from McMurdo Station, to test for atmospheric transport of microscopic organisms from the surface of coastal sea ice into the interior of the continent, where the microbes would be deposited and detected in snow and the upper surface of glacial ice formations.  To see if microbes survive the dangerous trip through the atmosphere, numerous large-volume samples of all the different ice types involved, from sea ice and surface frost flowers to snow and glacial ice, had to be collected and processed for DNA extraction and sequencing.  The successful collection and processing of these samples was a feat in itself, followed by analysis of the resulting DNA sequences.  The results were unexpected.  Whereas the delicate ice crystal structures known as frost flowers were expected to be the most readily airborne of the marine samples and thus to have their marine microbial inhabitants appear inland, the reverse transport process was implicated; that is, DNA sequences indicative of land-based microbes were found abundantly in the marine frost flowers.  These microbes appeared likely to have originated from the Mt. Erebus area near McMurdo Sound, a vastly understudied region that may hold clues to the type of microbes that are capable of withstanding long-term transport in the atmosphere and to their ultimate survival strategies in the air and in the ice.  During this work, the graduate student involved in the project connected from McMurdo Station to hundreds of students, in elementary to university classrooms in the USA and beyond, through a daily blog and real-time Skype calls for question and answer forums, engaging directly with the students on the scientific content and excitement of working in Antarctica.  A PhD dissertation was completed at the end of this project, leading to the award of a postdoctoral fellowship to continue Antarctic research; new training in extreme fieldwork was gained by team members; and products (protein samples and cultures) for possible downstream applications were acquired.
